workflow.name: Smarter RAG agents with enriched retrieval and modular workflows
workflow.description:
An extendable RAG template to build powerful, explainable AI assistants ‚Äî with query understanding, semantic metadata, and support for free-tier tools like Gemini, Gemma and Supabase.

## Description
This workflow helps you build smart, production-ready RAG agents that go far beyond basic document Q&A.

It includes:

‚úÖ File ingestion and chunking

‚úÖ Asynchronous LLM-powered enrichment

‚úÖ Filterable metadata-based search

‚úÖ Gemma-based query understanding and generation

‚úÖ Cohere re-ranking

‚úÖ Memory persistence via Postgres



Everything is modular, low-cost, and designed to run even with **free-tier LLMs and vector databases**.

Whether you want to build a chatbot, internal knowledge assistant, documentation search engine, or a filtered content explorer ‚Äî this is your foundation.


## ‚öôÔ∏è How It Works
This workflow is divided into 3 pipelines:

### üì• Ingestion
- Upload a PDF via form
- Extract text and chunk it for embedding
- Store in Supabase vector store using Google Gemini embeddings


### üß† Enrichment (Async)
- Scheduled task fetches new chunks
- Each chunk is enriched with LLM metadata (topics, use_case, risks, audience level, summary, etc.)
- Metadata is added to the vector DB for improved retrieval and filtering


### ü§ñ Agent Chat
- A user question triggers the RAG agent
- Query Builder transforms it into keywords and filters
- Vector DB is queried and reranked
- The final answer is generated using only retrieved evidence, with references
- Chat memory is managed via Postgres

## üåü Key Features
- **Asynchronous enrichment** ‚Üí Save tokens, batch process with free-tier LLMs like Gemma
- **Metadata-aware** ‚Üí Improved filtering and reranking
- **Explainable answers** ‚Üí Agent cites sources and sections
- **Chat memory** ‚Üí Persistent context with Postgres
- **Modular design** ‚Üí Swap LLMs, rerankers, vector DBs, and even enrichment schema
- **Free to run** ‚Üí Built with Gemini, Gemma, Cohere, Supabase (free tier-compatible)



## üîê Required Credentials

|Tool|Use|
|-|-|-|
|Supabase w/ PostreSQL|Vector DB + storage|
|Google Gemini/Gemma|Embeddings & LLM|
|Cohere API|Re-ranking|
|PostgreSQL|Chat memory|



## üß∞ Customization Tips
- Swap extractFromFile with Notion/Google Drive integrations

- Extend Metadata Obtention prompt to fit your domain (e.g., financial, legal)

- Replace LLMs with OpenAI, Mistral, or Ollama 

- Replace Postgre Chat Memory with Simple Memory or any other

- Use a webhook instead of a form to automate ingestion

- Connect to Telegram/Slack UI with a few extra nodes


## üí° Use Cases
- Company knowledge base bot (internal docs, SOPs)

- Educational assistant with smart filtering (by topic or level)
- Legal or policy assistant that cites source sections
- Product documentation Q&A with multi-language support
- Training material assistant that highlights risks/examples
- Content Generation


## üß† Who It‚Äôs For
- Indie developers building smart chatbots
- AI consultants prototyping Q&A assistants
- Teams looking for an internal knowledge agent
- Anyone building affordable, explainable AI tools

## üöÄ Try It Out!

Deploy a modular RAG assistant using n8n, Supabase, and Gemini ‚Äî fully customizable and almost free to run.

#### 1. üìÅ Prepare Your PDFs

- Use any internal documents, manuals, or reports in **PDF **format.

- Optional: Add Google Drive integration to automate ingestion.

#### 2. üß© Set Up Supabase

- Create a free Supabase project

- Use the table creation queries included in the workflow to set up your schema.

- Add your *supabaseUrl *and *supabaseKey *in your n8n credentials.

> üí° Pro Tip:
Make sure you match the embedding dimensions to your model.
This workflow uses *Gemini text-embedding-04* (768-dim) ‚Äî if switching to OpenAI, change your table vector size to 1536.

#### 3. üß† Connect Gemini & Gemma

- Use Gemini/Gemma for embeddings and optional metadata enrichment.

- Or deploy locally for lightweight async LLM processing (via Ollama/HuggingFace).

#### 4. ‚öôÔ∏è Import the Workflow in n8n

- Open n8n (self-hosted or cloud).

- Import the workflow file and paste your credentials.


You‚Äôre ready to ingest, enrich, and query your document base.


## üí¨ Have Feedback or Ideas? I‚Äôd Love to Hear

This project is open, modular, and evolving ‚Äî just like great workflows should be :).

If you‚Äôve tried it, built on top of it, or have suggestions for improvement, I‚Äôd genuinely love to hear from you. Let‚Äôs share ideas, collaborate, or just connect as part of the n8n builder community.

üìß [ascuncia.es@gmail.com](mailto:ascuncia.es+n8ncreator@gmail.com)

üîó [Linkedin](https://www.linkedin.com/in/alejandro-scuncia-60a62348/)

workflow.name: Smarter RAG Agents with Enriched Retrieval, Filters & Memory - by ascuncia

values.content:
=You are a metadata enricher for arbitrary business documents (guides, manuals, best practices, policies, FAQs, playbooks).

TASK
Analyze the provided TEXT CHUNK and return a SINGLE-LINE, MINIFIED JSON object (no backticks, no prose). Use ONLY what is explicitly present or safely implied by the chunk. If a field does not apply, use null or [] accordingly.

INPUTS
- chunk_text: {{ $json.content }}
- file metadata (for disambiguation only; DO NOT copy values if not present in the chunk):
  - doc_title: {{ $json.metadata.doc_title }}
  - doc_type: {{ $json.metadata.doc_type }}

OUTPUT SCHEMA (exact keys; keep values short and consistent):
{
  "topics": ["keyword1","keyword2"],             // up to 8
  "feature": "short_tag",                         // e.g., "workspaces", "databases", "onboarding", "security"
  "use_case": "short_tag",                        // e.g., "workspace_structure", "communication", "setup", "policy"
  "audience": "beginner|intermediate|advanced|null",
  "section": "section_or_heading_if_any",
  "entities": ["product|role|team|concept"],      // proper names or domain terms
  "key_recommendations": ["bullet1","bullet2"],   // up to 5 concise, actionable bullets
  "risks_or_pitfalls": ["risk1","risk2"],         // up to 5; [] if none
  "examples_present": true,                       // whether the chunk includes an example
  "language": "auto_detected_iso_639_1",          // e.g., "en", "es", "pt", "it"; infer from chunk_text
  "chunk_summary": "1-2 sentence neutral summary" // plain, factual, grounded in the chunk
}

GUIDELINES
- Prefer concrete nouns/verbs over vague words.
- Do not invent entities or recommendations; keep them grounded in the text.
- If multiple candidates exist, choose the most central one (or null).
- Deduplicate arrays; keep strings on a single line; no trailing punctuation in bullets.

RETURN ONLY THE MINIFIED JSON, ONE LINE.

=You are a query builder for a document retrieval system (RAG). 
Your task: analyze the user‚Äôs question and output ONE SINGLE-LINE, MINIFIED JSON. No prose.

OUTPUT SCHEMA (always valid JSON, one line):
{
  "keywords": ["k1","k2","k3"],          // up to 6 short terms from the question
    "filters": {                           // OPTIONAL filters; include only if clearly implied, domain specific - do not include
  }
}

RULES
- Keep keywords concise; avoid stop-words or full sentences.
- Only add filters if the intent is clear from the question.
- If the user just greets or provides no query, return {"keywords":[]} with no filters.


OUTPUT
- Output ONLY valid JSON, minified, one single line.
- Do NOT add ```json, code fences, or any text before/after.
- Do NOT include newlines.

INPUT
{{ $json.chatInput }}

NOTE
- Domain-specific logic (e.g., mapping to product features, principles, policies) can be added here in future.

options.systemMessage:
=You are a friendly but objective RAG assistant. You may only answer using passages returned by the tool "Supabase Vector Store". 
If in this turn you did not call the tool at least once, reply:
"I don't have enough evidence in the indexed documents to answer this."

LANGUAGE
- Always answer in the user's language. Detect automatically from the user message.

RECOVERY QUERY
- Use the JSON line produced by "Query Builder". If it contains multiple keywords or filters, pass them to the retrieval tool.
- If the query is ambiguous, still retrieve with general keywords and let the reranker select the best contexts.

ANSWER RULES
"
- Prefer 2‚Äì4 distinct passages. If only 1 is available, say evidence is limited. Always form a concrete answer with the passages, not lost sentences.
- Do NOT import outside knowledge. If relevant passages are weak or missing, say so and suggest a clearer question.
- If the user's message is just a greeting (e.g., "hi"), do NOT call tools. Respond with a short greeting and invite a question.

OUTPUT STYLE
- Concise, friendly but objective.
- Add a section below with References, with the format
  "Source: <doc_title> ‚Äî <section>. Use a title for the section and bullets.
- No hallucinations; everything must be grounded in retrieved text.

FAILSAFE
- If retrieval returns authors/topics unrelated to the user's intent, ignore them and state that no relevant evidence was found.

metadataValues.name: topics
metadataValues.value: ={{ (() => { try { const t = JSON.parse(($('Query Builder').item.json.content?.parts?.[0]?.text || '{}')).filters?.topics; return Array.isArray(t) && t.length ? t : undefined } catch(e){ return undefined } })() }}

metadataValues.name: entities
metadataValues.value: ={{ (() => { try { const t = JSON.parse(($('Query Builder').item.json.content?.parts?.[0]?.text || '{}')).filters?.entities; return Array.isArray(t) && t.length ? t : undefined } catch(e){ return undefined } })() }}

parameters.toolDescription:
=Semantic retrieval tool. Queries the "documents" table and returns passages with metadata.

Usage by the agent:
- Always use the JSON line produced by the Query Builder to form keywords and (optional) metadata filters.
- If scope is "multi_document", allow results from multiple documents; otherwise bias to a single document if clearly implied.
Output: fragments with metadata.doc_title, section (if any), feature, use_case, topics, chunk_summary.

parameters.content:
## üü© File Ingestion Pipeline

Extracts and chunks uploaded PDFs.
Embeds content and stores it in Supabase vector DB.
Clean and modular, ready for other sources (Notion, Drive, etc).

## üü® Enrichment Pipeline (Async)

Enriches chunks with semantic metadata using a lightweight LLM.
Improves retrieval and enables filters like audience, use_case, risks.
Runs asynchronously to reduce cost ‚Äî ideal for free-tier models.

## üü¶ RAG Agent Pipeline

Handles user questions with memory, filtering, reranking, and references.
Powered by a Query Builder + Cohere Reranker + Gemini LLM.
Answers only with retrieved content ‚Äî safe, explainable, production-grade.

## üß© Prepare the Database (SQL)

Now we‚Äôll build the foundation that powers search, enrichment, and retrieval ‚Äî think of it as creating the ‚Äúsemantic filing system‚Äù for your document library.

### ‚úÖ **Action Steps:**

- In your Supabase project, open the SQL Editor.

- Locate the sticky note below that includes the full SQL schema.

- Copy the entire SQL code, paste it into the editor, and click ‚ÄúRUN‚Äù.

### ‚ö†Ô∏è **Heads-Up:**

- If you get an error saying pgvector already exists, simply delete the first line of the code (create extension vector;) and run it again.

- This workflow uses Gemini embeddings with 768 dimensions.
‚Üí If you're switching to OpenAI embeddings, you must update the schema line:
Change vector(768) to vector(1536) to match the correct dimensions.


### SQL

-- üßπ (Optional) Clean up any previous table for fresh setup
drop table documents;

-- üß† Enable pgvector to store and search vector embeddings
create extension vector;

-- üìö Create the main table to store your document chunks
create table documents (
  id bigserial primary key,         -- Unique ID for each chunk
  content text,                     -- The chunk content (pageContent)
  metadata jsonb,                   -- Metadata like filename, section, topic, etc.
  embedding vector(768)             -- Gemini embedding vector (768 dims)
                                    -- ‚ö†Ô∏è If using OpenAI: change to vector(1536)
);

-- üîß Drop older or conflicting versions of the matching function
drop function if exists public.match_documents(jsonb, int, vector);
drop function if exists public.match_documents(int, vector, jsonb);
drop function if exists public.match_documents(vector, int);

-- üîç Create a custom function to perform vector search with optional filters
create or replace function public.match_documents (
  query_embedding vector(768),      -- Input embedding from user query
  match_count int,                  -- Number of results to return
  filter jsonb default '{}'::jsonb -- Optional filter using metadata
)
returns table (
  id bigint,
  content text,
  metadata jsonb,
  embedding vector(768),
  similarity float                  -- Cosine similarity score
)
language sql stable
as $$
  select
    id,
    content,
    metadata,
    embedding,
    1 - (embedding <#> query_embedding) as similarity  -- Cosine similarity = 1 - distance
  from documents
  where (filter is null or filter = '{}'::jsonb or metadata @> filter)
  order by embedding <#> query_embedding                -- Order by closest match
  limit match_count;
$$;

user.name: Alejandro Scuncia
user.bio:
Support & Services Leader exploring GenAI and automation.

Currently leading a global support team while building and learning through real-world AI workflows ‚Äî from smarter knowledge agents to complex integrations.

Here to explore, share, and connect with the n8n community.
